repo.name: neovim

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -216,4 +216,15 @@ describe('vim.snippet', function()
     feed('foo')
     eq({ 'public function foo() {', '\t', '}' }, buf_lines(0))
   end)
+
+  it('jumps through adjacent tabstops', function ()
+    test_expand_success(
+    { 'for i=1,${1:to}${2:,step} do\n\t$3\nend' },
+    { 'for i=1,to,step do', '\t', 'end' })
+    sleep(10)
+    feed('10')
+    feed('<Tab>')
+    feed(',2')

comment_data.body: Could you please explain the difference between `sleep` and `poke_eventloop`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -216,4 +216,15 @@ describe('vim.snippet', function()
     feed('foo')
     eq({ 'public function foo() {', '\t', '}' }, buf_lines(0))
   end)
+
+  it('jumps through adjacent tabstops', function ()
+    test_expand_success(
+    { 'for i=1,${1:to}${2:,step} do\n\t$3\nend' },
+    { 'for i=1,to,step do', '\t', 'end' })
+    sleep(10)
+    feed('10')
+    feed('<Tab>')
+    feed(',2')

comment_data.body:
- `sleep()` uses a hard-coded timeout.
- `poke_eventloop()` waits for all the pending input to be processed.

Without either `sleep()` or `poke_eventloop()`, the next `feed()` may arrive before the `feedkeys()` in `select_tabstop()` is reached, causing incorrect ordering of input keys.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -216,4 +216,15 @@ describe('vim.snippet', function()
     feed('foo')
     eq({ 'public function foo() {', '\t', '}' }, buf_lines(0))
   end)
+
+  it('jumps through adjacent tabstops', function ()
+    test_expand_success(
+    { 'for i=1,${1:to}${2:,step} do\n\t$3\nend' },
+    { 'for i=1,to,step do', '\t', 'end' })
+    sleep(10)
+    feed('10')
+    feed('<Tab>')
+    feed(',2')

comment_data.body: And... `poke_eventloop()` is needed after the `<Tab>` because input is queued, but it is not needed after `test_expand_success()` because `exec_lua()` doesn't return until the code is fully executed.

comment_regular_data.body: Ehhh idk what's up with the tests, why is `sleep` undefined in some cases?
Because you never assigned any value to it?

> Because you never assigned any value to it?

I did.
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/066fa77a964f5effcb26bfda243337bf027f0175/test/functional/lua/snippet_spec.lua#L10

And if that had not been the case, _all_ tests would fail wouldn't it?
